name: Young Life
description: John Muir was born in the small stone house aside the Lorne Hotel on April 21, 1838. He was the third of eight children, and would spend much of his childhood in the countryside of Dunbar. Despite his father’s insistence on relentless bible study, Muir cultivated a love of the outdoors and oft wandered the countryside, which earned him a fair number of lashings.

name: Immigration and Settlement in America
description: In 1849, Muir’s family emigrated from Scotland and landed in Portage Wisconsin, on a farm called Fountain Lake. Muir spent a while here, and at his father’s behest, learned bible from an evangelical group called the Disciples of Christ. Muir would always remain a deeply spiritual man, but eventually his orthodox beliefs left him. By his own words, “…they went away of their own accord…without leaving any consciousness of loss.”

name: College Years
description: At 22 years old, Muir enrolled at the University of Winconsin-Madison. Here, he received his first botany lesson, studied chemistry with a professor Ezra Carr, and cultivated his knowledge of the outdoors. He never would graduate from college, he just studied what he wanted for three years, and left without a degree.

name: Travel to Canada
description: Muir, as a young man, worked his way up to Ontario in Canada West. He hiked along the edges of Georgian bay, picking plants and seeing the land. Eventually however, his money ran low, and he joined his brother in Meaford, Ontario to work at a saw and rake factory. He lived here for a while until his wanderlust overtook him again and he left to return to the United States.

name: Seeing the World Anew
description: John Muir left to work at a wagon wheel factory in Indianapolis. There, he almost lost his sight in an industrial accident, and vowed forevermore to explore the world, claiming he sees the world in a new light. He traveled south to Florida, to Cedar Keys where he worked at a sawmill. Eventually his wanderlust made him take a boat to Havana, New York City, and eventually California.

name: Yosemite
description: John Muir would spend many years in Yosemite. A guide, backwoodsman, and naturalist, Muir spent nearly all of his days in this period penniless and jobless. He built his own cabin in Yosemite Valley, and would often go out into the wildness with a little bit of tea, a little loaf of bread, his clothes, and a copy of the writings of Ralph Waldo Emerson.

name: Oakland and World Travel
description: John Muir would publish a number of articles detailing the history of Yosemite, and his hypothesis that it was carved by glaciers, and not by earthquake as was the prevailing theory. He also published a series of articles entitled “Studies in the Sierra”. In this time, Muir traveled the world from South America, to Europe, and Alaska.

name: Ranching Life
description: In 1880, John Muir married Louie Wanda Strentzel and moved to Martinez, CA to settle down for a life of ranching and raising children. He did, however, continue to travel the world, seeing China, Japan, Europe, and Africa among others. His love, however, was always the Sierra Nevada, and he wrote extensively on environmental protection, and traveled to Yosemite often.

name: Activism and Environmentalism
description: John Muir published 300 articles and 10 books that recounted his life, and espoused the virtues of environmental protection. He founded the Sierra Club in 1892, and fought for the establishment of Yosemite National Park, as well as parks in Sequoia, Mount Rainier, Petrified Forest, and Grand Canyon. In 1901, he published “Our National Parks”, and through that book, got to meet with president Theodore Roosevelt. Together, they laid the foundations for the National Park system.
